div.l: That helpeth hym towasten and to sowke
Of that he brybe may can or borow may
Anoon he send his bedde and his array
Vnto a conꝑper of his owne sorte
That loued dys reuell and disport
And had a wyf that held fortħ contynaunce
A shoppe and swyfed for hir sustenaunce
But here of I will passe as now
Of ȝong Gamelyn I will telle ꝫow .
Lythen and lightenyth ⁊and herkenygħ aryꝫt
And ȝe shuƚƚ here of a doughty knyght
Sir Iohn̄ of Bondeux was his name
He coude of norture and of mycħ game .
Thre sōnnes the knyght had ⁊and with his body hēm wan͒
The eldest was a moche shrew ⁊and sone he bygan
His bretheren loued wele hir fader ⁊and were of hȳm agast
The eldest deseruyd his fader curs ⁊and he hit had at last
The goode knyght his fader lyued so ȝore
That deth was cōmmyn hym to ⁊and handelyd hym ful sore
The goode knyght cared sore syke ther he lay
How his children shuld lyven after his day
He had ben̄ wyde where but housbond non̄ he was
Aƚƚ the land that he had hit was purchas
Fayn he wold hit were dressyd among hem aƚƚ
That iche of hem had his ꝑparte as hit might falle
Tho send he in to the contre after wise knyghtes
To help to delen̄ his landes ⁊and dressen̄ hēm to rightes
He send hem word by l͒letres ther shuld hie blyve
Ȝif thei wold speke with hym while he was o lyve
Tho the knyghtes herden̄ sike that he lay
Hadde thei no rest nother nyght than day
Tiƚƚ ther come to hym ther he lay stille
